Alma Families:

Since the global pandemic began last Spring, Alma del Mar has been committed to providing access for all scholars to participate in remote learning.

Unfortunately, Chromebooks are limited across the entire country right now. We have a very large order coming our way, but they will not be ready for distribution next week as planned. Because of this, we will be prioritizing Chromebook distribution for Kindergarten families next week.

This means we are asking for as many families as possible to use personal devices for the time being if they do not already have Chromebooks. *This is only temporary.*

We are committed to having 1 device per 1 scholar as soon as possible. The issue, right now, is simply availability.

Families who received Chromebooks last spring: Please bring your *charged* devices with you to Orientation so your scholar may be shown how to access remote learning tools.

#EdThatAddsUp

An important update was sent out to our K-1 Families yesterday. We thought we'd share it with all of you:

We are no longer planning on beginning the school year with all of Kindergarten and First Grade in person. Instead, they will join our 2nd-8th grade scholars in participating in remote learning.

If conditions allow, we plan to prioritize our K-1 scholars for returning back to in-person instruction in October.

We are still planning on serving a number of scholars in all grades who have complex needs with in person instruction instruction at the start of the year. This will be a small group to start with and then we will plan to expand it in October.

To be clear: This update does not change our re-opening plans for scholars entering Second through Eighth Grade, those scholars will still begin the year participating in remote learning from home. Now, when we begin our school year on September 14th, all scholars will be learning remotely, from home, unless they have been identified as part of a targeted group of scholars with high needs.

**Families whose students qualify for free or reduced-price lunch started to receive P-EBT cards in the mail on Friday, May 29. If you are having trouble activating your card, follow the information from the Department of Transitional Assistance (DTA):

You will need the letter DTA sent you in the mail to activate the card.

Call the EBT card phone number on the back of your P-EBT card: 800-997-2555.

Enter your P-EBT card number (it is an 18-digit number).

You will then be prompted incorrectly to enter the last four digits of your Social Security number. Do *not* enter the last 4 digits of your Social Security number. For the P-EBT cards, you must enter the last four digits of your child's *case number* that was provided on the DTA letter you received in the mail.

Then enter your child's date of birth using a two-digit month, two-digit day, and four-digit year (example: 04/06/2005).

For more information, visit: map-ebt.org. Questions? Call Project Bread's FoodSource Hotline at 800-645-8333.

This past fall we launched Families Helping Families, an Alma initiative run by the inimitable Alma parent and organizer Marie Tavares.Under Marie‚Äôs leadership, FHF has connected Alma families with each other, provided targeted support to parents in need and introduced Alma families to relevant social service organizations in New Bedford. We could not have predicted how urgent the work of FHF would become only months after its launch.

In the past four weeks, Marie, FHF volunteers and other Alma staff have provided dozens of Alma families in need with everything from infant formula and diapers to paper goods and safe drinking water. They‚Äôve picked up prescription medications for kids and delivered it along with school lunch to home bound parents. They‚Äôve connected families with information on unemployment insurance and other crisis relief services. FHF is letting our families know that they are not alone in this and that they can support and rely on each other.

*Audio: Play all sounds together through all speakers or play sound on startup.
